The customers could also be overwhelming, but they most always involved coupons. Advice to Management
I was hired as the first of a newly created position, so some disorganization was to be expected but Macy's as a whole is run much more haphazardly than I ever expected. The same carts I used to wheel out large amounts of product to stock were the same ones used as extra display tables, causing cart shortages when I needed them. Customers constantly asked for shopping carts, which Macy's no longer supplies. If an item was found out of place after a customer abandoned it (ex: a pillow in the candy section), associates could look up the section it came from (ex: home goods) and still have no idea where in that section it belongs, making it difficult and time consuming to put away. To my understanding, the fulfillment team has similar problems finding items customers requested. There is no map layout or merchandising plan to clear up confusion. The back stock rooms were numerous and rarely corresponded to the section it was near (ex: the store room in the men's winter coat section stores clearance; the store room in the clearance section stores polos). The computers are slow and old and the phones are so old it sounds like the person on the other end is underwater. HR would write work orders to fix problems, such as broken locks or doors, the moment they were requested but maintenance could take weeks to get to it, or even never fix it at all. The phone policy of no cell phone on the floor is unenforceable in some positions. I worked alone under the supervision of the second floor merchandising manager, but neither of us had a Macy's-supplied cordless phone to communicate (I do know there were a handful in HR) so whenever I needed to contact her she could be anywhere upstairs, in a back room, or down in shipping and receiving and I'd never find her. We had to bend official policy and use our cell phones to stay in contact and even the store manager approved because their was no other way. As I said, it was a new position, so they had estimated my hours but inevitably I was scheduled more than needed. Some days my work kept me busy all day, but it wasn't uncommon for me to finish in under two hours, only half an hour at my fastest, and still have the rest of a six or eight hour shift. The logical thing would have been for me to leave, but since I was technically a vendor paid by Frango to work at Macy's, I felt like they saw me as free labor. Admittedly, I did volunteer to work in other departments because I wouldn't be able to take the boredom of six hours of nothing to do but straighten, and I should have pushed harder to better explain that overworking myself would lead to longer time off due to my disability, but ultimately I felt pressured to "try" their schedules because I could never give a definitive answer as to what would set me off. I felt stressed and generally used while working there a lot of the time and was not eager to continue, but that was more of a unique situation to me. For everyone else who works at Macy's, I would hope someone reevaluates the organizational structure of the company and make things easier on its employees.

The management team at this location varies in ability. You have a handful of competent managers who know what they’re doing and a ton that don’t, mainly because they were promoted too young or don’t posses the requisite skill sets for the jobs they have. The culture is also a major issue. Sales Associates at White Plains are routinely abused by unruly and obnoxious customers. Store policies change on a dime and are not well received by customers who blame associates. It also doesn’t help that the company sends out coupons without properly articulating what they are good for just to get customers in the door who then blame associates when they can’t use said coupons. Managers are generally unhelpful and hide in their offices. Their attitudes are also extremely poor in dealing with their subordinates. With the exception of a few, most set unrealistic goals for their teams and lash out at them when they can’t accomplish these goals. Most of these goals are related to maintaining standards and recovery. You’ll have 1 or maybe 2 associates if you’re lucky for an entire department, left to deal with lines of customers, clean fitting rooms and recover fixtures all by themselves without any help from their managers who are constantly off gossiping in their offices. Managers will almost always yell at associates for not recovering their areas, calling them lazy, when in reality one associate is juggling the responsibilities of 3-4 associates while assisting customers. We’re also never allowed to acknowledge that we keep getting asked to do more while the company continues to shrink the number of associates assigned to each area. It constantly feels like you’re being set up to fail. Some managers are decent and join their associates on the proverbial front lines to assist when necessary and are genuinely pleasant to work with. Others see themselves more as “executives” and sniff their nose at the thought of doing any task an associate typically does.
